articles.title: Greetings to President of Cote d'Ivoire
Greetings to Jamaican Prime Minister
articles.content:
Greetings to President of Cote d'Ivoire 
    Pyongyang, August 6 (KCNA) -- Kim Yong Nam, president of the Presidium of the DPRK Supreme People's Assembly, Friday sent a message of greetings to Laurent Gbagbo, president of Cote d'Ivoire, on the occasion of the 46th anniversary of its independence.
 The message sincerely wished the president and people of Cote d'Ivoire good fruition in their efforts for peace and stability of the country and national unity, expressing the belief that the friendly relations between the two countries would continue to develop favorably.

articles.title: All-Out Struggle for Independence and Peace Declared in S. Korea
articles.content:
Greetings to Jamaican Prime Minister 
    Pyongyang, August 6 (KCNA) -- Premier of the DPRK Cabinet Pak Pong Ju sent a message of greetings to Jamaican Prime Minister Portia Simpson Miller on the occasion of the 44th anniversary of independence of Jamaica.
 Expressing the conviction that the friendly and cooperative relations existing between the two countries would continue to grow stronger, the message wished the prime minister and the government of Jamaica success in their work for the prosperity of the country and the welfare of its people.

articles.title: Vanguard for Reunification Formed in S. Korea
articles.content:
All-Out Struggle for Independence and Peace Declared in S. Korea 
    Pyongyang, August 6 (KCNA) -- The Reunification Solidarity of south Korea reportedly called a press conference on July 27 at which it declared the July 27-August 15 all-out struggle for achieving independence and peace of the Korean Peninsula.
 A press release read out at the press conference said the situation on the Korean Peninsula is growing tenser due to the U.S. persistent hostile policy towards the DPRK, underscoring the need to intensify the anti-U.S. actions to achieve independence and peace on the peninsula.    
 The Reunification Solidarity will set the period from July 27 to August 15 as a period of the all-out struggle and conduct sustained practical actions for achieving independence, peace and great national unity and channel all efforts of the people to the struggle for frustrating the U.S. policy of domination, noted the press release.

articles.title: Struggle against Harasser of Global Peace Called for
articles.content:
Vanguard for Reunification Formed in S. Korea 
    Pyongyang, August 6 (KCNA) -- The South Headquarters of the National Alliance of Youth and Students for the Country's Reunification reportedly held a ceremony in Seoul on August 2 to inaugurate the vanguard for reunification at which it called upon the youth and students to dynamically turn out in the anti-U.S. struggle for peace and reunification.
 Speakers at the inaugural ceremony said through the activities of the vanguard for reunification it would fully disclose the fact that the U.S. is chiefly to blame for escalating the tension on the Korean Peninsula and energetically conduct mass political work and build up public opinion to encourage all people to work hard for national cooperation.    
 An action program for the vanguard was made public at the ceremony. It called for conducting an all-people signature campaign demanding a total renegotiation of the plan for the expansion of the U.S. military base in Phyongthaek and checking the conclusion of the south Korea-U.S. FTA, staging actions for the withdrawal of the U.S. troops and holding anti-U.S. meetings in front of U.S. forces bases.
 Kim Tae Hyong, chairman of the General Student Council of Chosun University was elected leader of the vanguard.

articles.title: Meeting in Japan to Settle Issue of Remains of Korean Victims of Forcible Drafting
Moves to Perpetuate U.S. Forces' Presence in S. Korea under Fire
articles.content:
Meeting in Japan to Settle Issue of Remains of Korean Victims of Forcible Drafting 
    Tokyo, August 3 (KNS-KCNA) -- A meeting for settling the issue of remains of Korean victims of forcible drafting was held in Tokyo on July 29 under the co-sponsorship of Japanese public, religious and civic organizations.
 Satosi Ueski, co-representative of the National Executive Committee of the Meeting for Settling the Issue of Remains of Korean Victims of Forcible Drafting and initiator of the Society for Thinking of War Victims in the Asia-Pacific Region, said in a keynote report that the government should not use the issue of remains, a humanitarian matter, as a diplomatic card but retract its decision to disallow the entry into Japan of a delegation of bereaved families of Korean victims of forcible drafting.
 As the Japan government is directly to blame for forcible drafting of Koreans, it should officially inform the bereaved families of the discussion on the issue of remains of victims and apologize to them.    
 The meeting was addressed by public figures of Japan, Vice-Chairman of the Central Standing Committee of the General Association of Korean Residents in Japan Ko Tok U who is head of the Central Headquarters of the Korean Side of the Group for Probing the Truth behind the Forcible Drafting of Koreans and representatives of bereaved families of victims of forcible drafting from south Korea. Screened at the meeting was a videotape related to the bereaved families of victims in the northern half of Korea.
 The meeting adopted a decision to submit a written request to the Japanese government in connection with the issue of remains.
